questions.text: Dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca: dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ, māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva kim akurvata sañjaya.
questions.translation: Dhṛtarāṣṭra said: O Sañjaya, after assembling in the place of pilgrimage at Kurukṣetra, what did my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu do, being desirous to fight?

questions.text: sañjaya uvāca: dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanas tadā, ācāryam upasaṅgamya rājā vacanam abravīt.
questions.translation: Sañjaya said: O King, after looking over the army gathered by the sons of Pāṇḍu, King Duryodhana went to his teacher and began to speak the following words.

questions.text: paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṁ camūm, vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā.
questions.translation: O my teacher, behold the great army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, so expertly arranged by your intelligent disciple, the son of Drupada.

questions.text: atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi, yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahā-rathaḥ.
questions.translation: Here in this army there are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhīma and Arjuna; there are also great fighters like Yuyudhāna, Virāṭa, and Drupada.

questions.text: dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ kāśirājaś ca vīryavān, purujit kuntibhojaś ca śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ.
questions.translation: There are also great, heroic, powerful fighters like Dhṛṣṭaketu, Cekitāna, Kāśirāja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Śaibya.

questions.text: yudhāmanyuś ca vikrānta uttamaujāś ca vīryavān, saubhadro draupadeyāś ca sarva eva mahā-rathāḥ.
questions.translation: There are the mighty Yudhāmanyu, the very powerful Uttamaujā, the son of Subhadrā, and the sons of Draupadī. All these warriors are great chariot fighters.

questions.text: asmākaṁ tu viśiṣṭā ye tān nibodha dvijottama, nāyakā mama sainyasya saṁjñārthaṁ tān bravīmi te.
questions.translation: O best of the brāhmaṇas, for your information, let me tell you about the captains who are especially qualified to lead my military force.

questions.text: bhavān bhīṣmaś ca karṇaś ca kṛpaś ca samitiñjayaḥ, aśvatthāmā vikarṇaś ca saumadattis tathaiva ca.
questions.translation: There are personalities like yourself, Bhīṣma, Karṇa, Kṛpa, Aśvatthāmā, Vikarṇa, and the son of Somadatta called Bhuriśravā, who are always victorious in battle.

questions.text: anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ, nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ sarve yuddha-viśāradāḥ.
questions.translation: There are many other heroes who are prepared to lay down their lives for my sake. All of them are well equipped with different kinds of weapons, and all are experienced in military science.

questions.text: aparyāptaṁ tad asmākaṁ balaṁ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam, paryāptaṁ tv idam eteṣāṁ balaṁ bhīmābhirakṣitam.
questions.translation: Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Grandfather Bhīṣma, whereas the strength of the Pāṇḍavas, carefully protected by Bhīma, is limited.

questions.text: ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathā-bhāgam avasthitāḥ, bhīṣmam evābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi.
questions.translation: Now all of you must give full support to Grandfather Bhīṣma, standing at your respective strategic points in the phalanx of the army.

questions.text: tasya sañjanayan harṣaṁ, kuru-vṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ, siṁha-nādaṁ vinadyoccaiḥ, śaṅkhaṁ dadhmau pratāpavān.

wordByWordMeaning.kuru-vṛddhaḥ: the grandsire of the Kuru dynasty (Bhīṣma).

questions.translation: Then Bhīṣma, the great valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, the grandfather of the fighters, blew his conchshell very loudly like the sound of a lion, giving Duryodhana joy.

questions.text: tataḥ śaṅkhāś ca bheryaś ca, paṇavānaka-gomukhāḥ, sahasaivābhyahanyanta, sa śabdas tumulo 'bhavat.
questions.translation: After that, the conchshells, bugles, trumpets, drums, and horns were all suddenly sounded, and the combined sound was tumultuous.

questions.text: tataḥ śvetair hayair yukte, mahati syandane sthitau, mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaś caiva, divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ.

wordByWordMeaning.mādhavaḥ: Krishna (the husband of the goddess of fortune).

questions.translation: On the other side, both Lord Krishna and Arjuna, stationed on a great chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their transcendental conchshells.

questions.text: pāñcajanyaṁ hṛṣīkeśo, devadattaṁ dhanañjayaḥ, pauṇḍraṁ dadhmau mahā-śaṅkhaṁ, bhīma-karmā vṛkodaraḥ.

wordByWordMeaning.hṛṣīkeśaḥ: Hṛṣīkeśa (Krishna, the Lord who directs the senses of the devotees).

questions.translation: Then, Lord Krishna blew His conchshell, called Pāñcajanya; Arjuna blew his, the Devadatta; and Bhīma, the voracious eater and performer of Herculean tasks, blew his terrific conchshell called Pauṇḍram.

questions.text: anantavijayaṁ rājā, kuntī-putro yudhiṣṭhiraḥ, nakulaḥ sahadevaś ca, sughoṣa-maṇipuṣpakau, kāśyaś ca parameṣvāsaḥ, śikhaṇḍī ca mahā-rathaḥ, dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaś ca, sātyakiś cāparājitaḥ, drupado draupadeyāś ca, sarvaśaḥ pṛthivī-pate, saubhadraś ca mahā-bāhuḥ, śaṅkhān dadhmuḥ pṛthak pṛthak.

wordByWordMeaning.sughoṣa-maṇipuṣpakau: the conches named Sughoṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka.
wordByWordMeaning.mahā-rathaḥ: one who can fight alone against thousands.
wordByWordMeaning.virāṭaḥ: Virāṭa (the prince who gave shelter to the Pāṇḍavas while they were in disguise).
wordByWordMeaning.sātyakiḥ: Sātyaki (the same as Yuyudhāna, the charioteer of Lord Kṛṣṇa).

questions.translation: King Yudhiṣṭhira, the son of Kuntī, blew his conchshell, the Anantavijaya, and Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughoṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka. That great archer, the King of Kāśī, the great fighter Śikhaṇḍī, Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa and the unconquerable Sātyaki, Drupada, the sons of Draupadī, and the others, O King, such as the son of Subhadrā, greatly armed, all blew their respective conchshells.

questions.text: sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṁ, hṛdayāni vyadārayat, nabhaś ca pṛthivīṁ caiva, tumulo 'bhyanunādayan.
questions.translation: The blowing of these different conchshells became uproarious, and thus, vibrating both in the sky and on the earth, it shattered the hearts of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.

questions.text: atha vyavasthitān dṛṣṭvā, dhārtarāṣṭrān kapi-dhvajaḥ, pravṛtte śastra-sampāte, dhanur udyamya pāṇḍavaḥ, hṛṣīkeśaṁ tadā vākyam, idam āha mahī-pate.

wordByWordMeaning.kapi-dhvajaḥ: one whose flag is marked with Hanumān.

questions.translation: O King, at that time Arjuna, the son of Pāṇḍu, who was seated in his chariot, his flag marked with Hanumān, took up his bow and prepared to shoot his arrows, looking at the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra. O King, Arjuna then spoke to Hṛṣīkeśa [Kṛṣṇa] these words.

questions.text: arjuna uvāca, senayor ubhayor madhye, rathaṁ sthāpaya me 'cyuta, yāvad etān nirīkṣe 'haṁ, yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān, kair mayā saha yoddhavyam, asmin raṇa-samudyame.
questions.translation: Arjuna said: O infallible one, please draw my chariot between the two armies so that I may see who is present here, who is desirous of fighting, and with whom I must contend in this great battle attempt.

questions.text: yotsyamānān avekṣe 'haṁ, ya ete 'tra samāgatāḥ, dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddher, yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavaḥ.
questions.translation: Let me see those who have come here to fight, wishing to please the evil-minded son of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.

questions.text: sañjaya uvāca, evam ukto hṛṣīkeśo, guḍākeśena bhārata, senayor ubhayor madhye, sthāpayitvā rathottamam.
questions.translation: Sañjaya said: O descendant of Bharata, being thus addressed by Arjuna, Lord Kṛṣṇa drew up the fine chariot in the midst of the armies of both parties.

questions.text: bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ, sarveṣāṁ ca mahīkṣitām, uvāca pārtha paśyaitān, samavetān kurūn iti.

wordByWordMeaning.kurūn: all the members of the Kuru dynasty.

questions.translation: In the presence of Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and all other chieftains of the world, Hṛṣīkeśa, the Lord, said, 'Just behold, Pārtha, all the Kurus who are assembled here.'

questions.text: tatrāpaśyat sthitān pārthaḥ, pitṝn atha pitāmahān, ācāryān mātulān bhrātṝn, putrān pautrān sakhīṁs tathā, śvaśurān suhṛdaś caiva, senayor ubhayor api.
questions.translation: There Arjuna could see, within the midst of the armies of both parties, his fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and also his father-in-law and well-wishers—all present there.

questions.text: tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ, sarvān bandhūn avasthitān, kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo, viṣīdann idam abravīt.
questions.translation: When the son of Kuntī, Arjuna, saw all these different grades of friends and relatives, he became overwhelmed with compassion and spoke thus.

questions.text: arjuna uvāca dṛṣṭvemaṁ svajanaṁ kṛṣṇa, yuyutsuṁ samupasthitam, sīdanti mama gātrāṇi, mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati.
questions.translation: Arjuna said: My dear Kṛṣṇa, seeing my friends and relatives present before me in such a fighting spirit, I feel the limbs of my body quivering and my mouth drying up.

questions.text: yasyāsti bhaktir bhagavaty akiñcanā, sarvair guṇais tatra samāsate surāḥ, harāv abhaktasya kuto mahad-guṇā, mano-rathenāsati dhāvato bahiḥ.

wordByWordMeaning.bhagavati: to the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
wordByWordMeaning.manaḥ-rathena: on the chariot of the mind (mental speculation).

questions.translation: One who has unflinching devotion for the Personality of Godhead has all the good qualities of the demigods. But one who is not a devotee of the Lord has only material qualifications that are of little value. This is because he is hovering on the mental plane and is certain to be attracted by the glaring material energy. (Bhāg. 5.18.12)

questions.text: vepathuś ca śarīre me, roma-harṣaś ca jāyate, gāṇḍīvaṁ sraṁsate hastāt, tvak caiva paridahyate.
questions.translation: My whole body is trembling, and my hair is standing on end. My bow Gāṇḍīva is slipping from my hand, and my skin is burning.

questions.text: na ca śaknomy avasthātuṁ, bhramatīva ca me manaḥ, nimittāni ca paśyāmi, viparītāni keśava.

wordByWordMeaning.keśava: O killer of the demon Keśī (Kṛṣṇa)

questions.translation: I am now unable to stand here any longer. I am forgetting myself, and my mind is reeling. I foresee only evil, O killer of the Keśī demon.

questions.text: na ca śreyo ’nupaśyāmi, hatvā svajanam āhave, na kāṅkṣe vijayaṁ kṛṣṇa, na ca rājyam sukhāni ca.
questions.translation: I do not see how any good can come from killing my own kinsmen in this battle, nor do I, O Kṛṣṇa, desire any subsequent victory, kingdom, or happiness.

questions.text: kiṁ no rājyena govinda, kiṁ bhogair jīvitena vā, yeṣām arthe kāṅkṣitaṁ no, rājyam bhogāḥ sukhāni ca...
questions.translation: O Govinda, of what avail to us are kingdoms, happiness, or even life itself when all those for whom we may desire them are now arrayed in this battlefield?
questions.interpretation: Arjuna laments that even if he wins, his victory will be meaningless because the very people he is fighting for—his teachers, elders, and relatives—will be lost in battle. He sees no joy in ruling a kingdom if it comes at the cost of their lives.

questions.text: pāpam evāśrayed asmān, hatvaitān ātatāyinaḥ, tasmān nārhā vayaṁ hantuṁ, dhārtarāṣṭrān svabāndhavān...

wordByWordMeaning.mādhava: O Kṛṣṇa, husband of the goddess of fortune

questions.translation: Sin will overcome us if we slay such aggressors. Therefore, it is not proper for us to kill the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra and our relatives. What should we gain, O Kṛṣṇa, husband of the goddess of fortune, and how could we be happy by killing our own kinsmen?
questions.interpretation: Arjuna argues that even though the Kauravas are aggressors, killing them would bring sin upon the Pāṇḍavas. He questions the righteousness of war if it leads to the destruction of his own family and loved ones, believing that no happiness can come from such an act.

questions.text: yadyapy ete na paśyanti, lobhopahata-cetasaḥ, kula-kṣaya-kṛtaṁ doṣaṁ, mitra-drohe ca pātakam...
questions.translation: O Janārdana, although these men, overtaken by greed, see no fault in killing one's family or quarreling with friends, why should we, who can see the crime in such acts, not refrain from committing this sin?
questions.interpretation: Arjuna contrasts himself with the Kauravas, saying that while they are blinded by greed and unable to see the consequences of their actions, the Pāṇḍavas—who understand dharma—should avoid committing the same mistakes. He argues that knowledge of sin should lead to avoidance of wrongdoing, emphasizing the moral responsibility of those who can foresee the consequences of their actions.

questions.text: kula-kṣaye praṇaśyanti, kula-dharmāḥ sanātanāḥ, dharme naṣṭe kulaṁ kṛtsnam, adharmo 'bhibhavaty uta
questions.translation: With the destruction of the dynasty, the eternal family tradition is vanquished, and thus the rest of the family becomes involved in irreligious practice.
questions.interpretation: Arjuna argues that war does not just result in the death of individuals but in the loss of family values and traditions. When elders perish, they can no longer guide the younger generations, leading to moral decline and the rise of irreligion (adharma). He sees this as a long-term societal threat, not just a personal loss.

questions.text: adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa, praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ, strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya, jāyate varṇa-saṅkaraḥ
questions.translation: When irreligion is prominent in the family, O Kṛṣṇa, the women of the family become corrupt, and from the degradation of womanhood, O descendant of Vṛṣṇi, comes unwanted progeny.
questions.interpretation: Arjuna fears that if war leads to the destruction of families, the absence of righteous men and elders will result in the moral decline of women. This would give rise to 'varṇa-saṅkara'—unwanted or mixed progeny—causing further disruption in the social and religious order. This reflects the Vedic concern for lineage purity and the structured functioning of society.

questions.text: doṣair etaiḥ kula-ghnānāṁ, varṇa-saṅkara-kārakaiḥ, utsādyante jāti-dharmāḥ, kula-dharmāś ca śāśvatāḥ

wordByWordMeaning.kula-ghnānām: of those who destroy the family

questions.translation: Due to the evil deeds of the destroyers of family tradition, all kinds of community projects and family welfare activities are devastated.

questions.text: utsanna-kula-dharmāṇāṁ, manuṣyāṇāṁ janārdana, narake niyataṁ vāso, bhavatīty anuśuśruma

wordByWordMeaning.kula-dharmāṇām: of those who have lost family traditions
wordByWordMeaning.janārdana: O Kṛṣṇa, maintainer of the people
wordByWordMeaning.anuśuśruma: I have heard from the disciplic succession

questions.translation: O Kṛṣṇa, maintainer of the people, I have heard from the disciplic succession that those who destroy family traditions always reside in hell.

questions.text: aho bata mahat pāpaṁ, kartuṁ vyavasitā vayam, yad rājya-sukha-lobhena, hantuṁ svajanam udyatāḥ

wordByWordMeaning.sukha-lobhena: driven by the greed for royal happiness

questions.translation: Alas, how strange it is that we are preparing to commit greatly sinful acts, driven by the desire to enjoy royal happiness.

questions.text: yadi mām apratīkāram, aśastraṁ śastra-pāṇayaḥ, dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyus, tan me kṣemataraṁ bhavet
questions.translation: I would consider it better for the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra to kill me unarmed and unresisting, rather than fight with them.

questions.text: sañjaya uvāca, evam uktvārjunaḥ saṅkhye, rathopastha upāviśat, visṛjya sa-śaraṁ cāpaṁ, śoka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ
questions.translation: Sañjaya said: Arjuna, having thus spoken on the battlefield, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot, his mind overwhelmed with grief.
questions.conclusion: Thus end the Bhaktivedanta Purports to the First Chapter of the Śrīmad-Bhagavad-gītā in the matter of Observing the Armies on the Battlefield of Kurukṣetra.
